title: Amygdaloid Island
listingDescription: Amygdaloid Island, found on Isle Royale National Park’s northern shore, offers a unique geological experience.

images.altText: View from rocky ridge with trees and Lake Superior in the background.
images.title: Amygdaloid Island
images.caption: Amygdaloid Island is found off the north shore of Isle Royale's main island.

bodyText:
Amygdaloid Island is located on the north shore of Isle Royale National Park. Amygdaloid Island includes rocky shores, forests, and a sea arch. A seasonally staffed ranger station and historic cabins populate the area near the dock on Amygdaloid Island's south shore. Overnight stay is not permitted. 

Found Nearby

  • McCargoe Cove & Campground
  • Belle Isle & Campground
  • Pickerel Cove & Campground
audioDescription: Amygdaloid Island is found on the north shore of Isle Royale National Park, near the mouth of McCargoe Cove. Known for its fascinating geology and presence of a sea arch. A ranger station and historic cabins can be found near the dock on the southern side of the island.

title: Boating Introduction
listingDescription: Permit, fees, itinerary- know all things boating before you venture to Isle Royale.

images.altText: Boats dock at Windigo.
images.title: Boater Picnic Windigo
images.caption: Plan ahead to ensure your trip to Isle Royale is relaxing.

bodyText:
Isle Royale National Park regulations are intended to protect park resources and visitor experiences. Visitors are responsible for adhering to regulations. The park’s boundary extends 4-1/2 miles into Lake Superior from the outer islands or to the international boundary. No pets allowed.
 

  • Isle Royale National Park Boating Regulations


Permits

All boaters staying overnight at anchor, at docks, or in campgrounds must first obtain a camping permit in-person at Houghton, Rock Harbor, or Windigo. Boaters may also obtain their permit in advance. Permits should be displayed on the boat when at anchor, at dock, or in the campground on a shelter or tent.
audioDescription: Isle Royale National Park is located in the northwest corner of Lake Superior. Boating is one of the main ways to explore around the island. The water is clear, cold, and can be moody.

title: Current Conditions at Isle Royale
listingDescription: Make sure to check the current conditions before your next trip to Isle Royale.

images.altText: A family of two adults and two children wearing large backpacks hikes through a forest meadow.
images.title: Family Backpacking on Isle Royale
images.caption: Check current conditions to know what to expect for your trip to Isle Royale.

bodyText:
Alerts & Closures

  • Winter Park Closure November 1 - April 15 annually: Isle Royale and its surrounding islands are closed to all visitors. Lake Superior waters are open to boaters. All islands reopen April 16.
  • All park visitor centers have closed for the season. This includes the Houghton, Rock Harbor, & Windigo Visitor Centers. For trip planning assistance, contact the park at 906-482-0984.
  • Navigational Buoys: Out for the season.
  • Rock Harbor Lighthouse: The tower is closed. The museum is closed for the season.
  • Cross-country camping zones 2023 Closures: 10, 9A, 8A, 12A, and 11A are closed due to the 2021 Horne Fire and the 2022 Mount Franklin Fire.

Safety for 2024

  • Your safety is your responsibility. Have a conservative trip plan, plan your gear with conditions in mind, be first aid ready, and have plans on what you might do in case something goes wrong. Self-rescue is the best rescue as park response is limited and help could be hours or days away. Come prepared with everything you may need.
  • Water is Life: Stay Hydrated. During the seaon, potable water is only available in Rock Harbor and Windigo. To be assured of no risk of contamination from small bacteria and viruses, all filtered water should be further treated with iodine or other approved chemical methods. 

Weather

  • Recreational Weather Forecast
  • Marine Forecast.

Facilities Closed Until May 2024

  • Potable Water:
    • Windigo: Not available.
    • Rock Harbor: Not available.
  • Restrooms:
    • Windigo: Closed.
    • Rock Harbor: Closed.
    • Bring toilet paper for use in outhouses.
  • Showers & Laundry
    • Windigo: Closed for the season.
    • Rock Harbor: Closed for the season.
  • Visitor Centers Hours
  • Rock Harbor Lodge 
    • Closed for the season. 
      • No services are available.
    • Fuel is not available.
  • Windigo Store: 
    • Closed for the season.
    • Fuel is not available.

Transportation Services

For 2024, Direct questions about transportation services and making reservations to respective providers. Dates sell out; reserve early.

Camping

  • General Conditions: Closed

Trails

  • General Conditions: Closed
  • Downed Trees: In Spring, trail crews will work to clear trails of downed trees across the island. However, obstructions will exist on trails and in campgrounds. Bring hiking poles to assist with difficult sections and wear sturdy, well-broken-in footwear.
  • Trail Navigation: Changing trail conditions due to beaver activity and wildfires from previous years can make certain sections of trail difficult to navigate. Have a map and compass and/or a GPS and know how to use them.

Water Conditions

  • N/A

Wildlife for 2024

  • Cow Moose with Calves: Cow moose are extremely protective of their calves. If you see a cow moose (no antlers), look to see if there is a calf around. If a cow moose were to approach, protect yourself by putting a large tree or rock between you and the moose.
  • Wolves: If you see a wolf, do not approach. If the wolf comes closer, encourage it to leave by clapping and yelling. If you cannot safely leave, make yourself big and aggressively use hiking poles or branches. Wolf attacks are extremely rare and unlikely to happen, but if it does, fight by any means necessary.

Buoys

Check if dive buoys are currently on or off station.

Customs

  • All recreational boaters intending to arrive at Isle Royale from Canada must clear U.S. customs prior to their arrival. This is true regardless of the nationality of the individual or purpose of the visit.
  • Private seaplanes cannot come directly to Isle Royale NP from Canada and utilize the ROAM app.
  • Learn more about clearing customs ahead of time.
audioDescription: Current Conditions keep visitors up to date on what is happening on Isle Royale.

title: Feldtmann Tower
listingDescription: The Feldtmann Fire Tower offers a unique 360 degree view of the west end of Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: Fire tower stands in tall grass surrounded by trees.
images.title: Feldtmann Tower ISRO
images.caption: Hike the Feltmann Loop and venture to the Feldtmann Fire Tower for scenic views of the west end.

bodyText:
The Feldtmann Fire Tower offers a unique west end view of Isle Royale National Park. It is located on the Feldtmann Ridge between Feldtmann Lake Campground and Siskiwit Campground. Formerly a fire tower, visitors can climb partly up the tower and experience a 360 degree view of Isle Royale's west end. Siskiwit Bay, Houghton Ridge, Siskiwit Ridge, and the Red Oak Ridge can all be viewed from the tower. This is an excellent spot for a lunch break while backpacking or a day excursion from nearby campgrounds. 

Found Nearby

  • Feldtmann Lake Campground (4.8 miles away)

  • Siskiwit Campground (5.4 miles away)

  • Rainbow Cove (5.6 miles away)
audioDescription: The Feldtmann Fire Tower is located on Isle Royale’s southwest end. The Feldtmann Fire Tower is found along the Feldtmann Ridge between Feldtmann Lake Campground and Siskiwit Campground. Those that climb the tower can enjoy a 360 view from the tower. Sisikiwit Bay, Houghton Ridge, Feldtmann Ridge, and the Red Oak Ridge can all be viewed from the tower.

title: First Timer's Guide to Isle Royale
listingDescription: Planning a trip to Isle Royale? Make sure to review this guide before your journey.

images.altText: Three people jump off a dock into water as one person watched while the sun sets.
images.title: Isle Royale Dock Jump
images.caption: Before you make the crossing to Isle Royale, spend time planning ahead and preparing for your trip.

bodyText:
When planning a trip to Isle Royale, many people ask, "What is the one thing I must do or see while I'm there?" The answer is, it depends on what type of Isle Royale experience you want to have! With a multitude of ways to travel to the park and numerous things to do once you arrive, compounded by the the island's large size and isolation in Lake Superior, Isle Royale adventures are as diverse as the thousands of people who come to the park each year. Despite these differences, the safest, most enjoyable trips are all grounded in planning and preparation that takes place before arrival. Using the information in this guide, plan an unforgettable experience to your national park.

 

First Timer's Guide
audioDescription: A guide for people visiting Isle Royale National Park for the first time. There are a variety of ways to recreate at Isle Royale including hiking, backpacking, paddling, and boating. The park's isolation and wilderness characteristic create challenges for those who dare to venture to this island in the northwest corner of Lake Superior.

title: Grace Creek Overlook
listingDescription: Grace Creek Overlook is a popular scenic day hike destination on the west end of Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: View from atop a ridge overlooking Grace Creek, forests, and the Red Oak Ridge on Isle Royale.
images.title: Grace Creek Overlook
images.caption: A hike to Grace Creek Overlook offers spectacular views.

bodyText:
Grace Creek Overlook is a popular scenic overlook on the west end of Isle Royale National Park. It is located off the Feldtmann Lake Trail about 1.8 miles south of Windigo. Step onto the rocky outcropping and gaze down at Grace Creek. Grace Beach, Grace Harbor, and Lake Superior can be viewed to the southwest. Wildlife viewing is common here. Hike to Grace Creek Overlook for the day and experience the island's vast wilderness. 

Found Nearby

  • Windigo Area (1.8 miles away)

  • Washington Harbor

  • Feldtmann Lake Campground (6.7 miles away)

  • Rainbow Cove (7.5 miles away)
audioDescription: Grace Creek Overlook, a popular day hike on Isle Royale, is located on the West End. A spur trail off of the Feldtmann Lake Trail leads to the overlook. After a 1.8-mile hike from Windigo on the Feldtmann Lake Trail, a spur trail and sign lead the way to the overlook. Grace Creek, Grace Beach, Grace Harbor, and Lake Superior can all be viewed from the overlook. This is a great area to see wildlife.

title: Greenstone Ridge Trailhead: Hidden Lake
listingDescription: Backpack the entire island of Isle Royale National Park by hiking the Greenstone Ridge Trail starting at the Hidden Lake.

images.altText: Wooden trail Marker for Greenstone Ridge Trail
images.title: Greenstone Ridge Trail Marker
images.caption: Backpack the Greenstone Ridge Trail and trek across the island of Isle Royale.

bodyText:
Backpack Isle Royale National Park and trek the Greenstone Ridge Trail that connects the southwest end to the northeast end of the island. The island’s longest trail includes forested wilderness, rocky exposed ridges, inland lakes, swamps, wildlife, and Lake Superior views.

Trailhead Locations
•  Windigo is accessible by ferry, seaplane, or private boat. 
•  Hidden Lake is accessible by private boat or water taxi from Rock Harbor Lodge. 

Miles: about 41.7

Accessibility: This backcountry trail is about 18 inches wide and includes rocks and roots. Trail includes wooden plank bridges and steep inclines.  No potable water is available along the trail. Bring everything you need to backpack multiple days across the island, including enough food, water filter, map, and compass.

Campgrounds Along Trail
•  Washington Creek Campground
•  Island Mine Campground
•  South Lake Desor Campground
•  Hatchet Lake Campground
•  West Chickenbone Campground
•  East Chickenbone Campground
•  Daisy Farm Campground
•  Three Mile Campground
•  Rock Harbor Campground
audioDescription: The Greenstone Ridge Trail connects the southwest end of Isle Royale to the northeast end. The trail includes forests, rocky ridges, swamps, inland lakes, wildlife, and wilderness. All campgrounds are backcountry campgrounds.

title: Greenstone Ridge Trailhead: Windigo
listingDescription: Backpack the entire island of Isle Royale National Park by hiking the Greenstone Ridge Trail starting at Windigo.

images.altText: Wooden trail Marker for Greenstone Ridge Trail
images.title: Greenstone Ridge Trail Marker
images.caption: Backpack the Greenstone Ridge Trail and trek across the island of Isle Royale.

bodyText:
Backpack Isle Royale National Park and trek the Greenstone Ridge Trail that connects the southwest end to the northeast end of the island. The island’s longest trail includes forested wilderness, rocky exposed ridges, inland lakes, swamps, wildlife, and Lake Superior views.

Trailhead Locations
•  Windigo is accessible by ferry, seaplane, or private boat. 
•  Hidden Lake is accessible by private boat or water taxi from Rock Harbor Lodge. 

Miles: about 41.7

Accessibility: This backcountry trail is about 18 inches wide and includes rocks and roots. Trail includes wooden plank bridges and steep inclines.  No potable water is available along the trail. Bring everything you need to backpack multiple days across the island, including enough food, water filter, map, and compass.

Campgrounds Along Trail
•  Washington Creek Campground
•  Island Mine Campground
•  South Lake Desor Campground
•  Hatchet Lake Campground
•  West Chickenbone Campground
•  East Chickenbone Campground
•  Daisy Farm Campground
•  Three Mile Campground
•  Rock Harbor Campground
audioDescription: The Greenstone Ridge Trail connects the southwest end of Isle Royale to the northeast end. The trail includes forests, rocky ridges, swamps, inland lakes, wildlife, and wilderness. All campgrounds are backcountry campgrounds.

title: Group Camping Introduction
listingDescription: Camping with a group of 7 people or more? Make sure to know everything about group camping before your trip.

images.altText: Scattered camping gear hangs to dry on a porch after a backpacking trip.
images.title: Post Backpacking Trip
images.caption: Have a group of 7 or more? Make sure to follow Group Camping Regulations to reduce your impact.

bodyText:
Things to Know about Group Camping

  • Advance group camping reservations and permits are required for groups of seven or more people, including leaders.
  • If your party exceeds ten, you must split into two or more groups (of ten or less), each independent and traveling on completely separate itineraries. For groups of ten or more people breaking up into small parties (1-6 people), a permit must still be obtained in advance.
  • Groups of seven or more people may only camp in reserved group campsites.
  • Organizations may not have more than 20 people camping on the island at any one time and are limited to 80 people per year.

Group Camping Reservation Requests

Isle Royale accepts group camping reservation requests beginning January 2 for the 2024 season. The park strives to process all requests quickly. However, due to limited winter staffing, we are not able to process most requests until March, when staffing increases.

All requests are processed in the order we receive them.
For more information, head over to our in-depth group camping page.
audioDescription: Group Camping is available at some, but not all, campgrounds at Isle Royale. The group campsites offer a larger area to fit more tent pads.

title: Ishpeming Tower
listingDescription: Ishpeming Fire Tower, located on Isle Royale National Park, offers a glimspe of conservation’s past.

images.altText: Old fire tower in a forest.
images.title: Ishpeming Tower
images.caption: The retired Ishpeming Fire Tower sits in a forest on Isle Royale National Park.

bodyText:
Ishpeming Fire Tower is one of three fire towers on Isle Royale National Park. Ishpeming Fire Tower is located at the junction of the Greenstone Ridge Trail and the Ishpeming Trail. The tower is no longer staffed but is an excellent spot for a hiking break. Although visitors cannot climb this tower, it does provide shelter from rainy weather with forest views. 

Found Nearby

  • Malone Campground
  • South Desor Campground
  • Hatchet Lake Campground
  • Greenstone Ridge Trail
audioDescription: Ishpeming Fire Tower is located on Isle Royale National Park. The tower is located at the junction of the Greenstone Ridge Trail and the Ishpeming Trail. Ishpeming Fire Tower offers forest views and shelter from rain.

title: Isle Royale Lighthouse
listingDescription: The Isle Royale Light stands on long, rocky Menagerie Island via Isle Royale's south shore at the entry to Siskiwit Bay.

images.altText: lighthouse sitting on rocky Menagerie Island on a blue sky day
images.title: Isle Royale Lighthouse
images.caption: The Isle Royale Lighthouse guards the rocky entrance to Siskiwit Bay.

bodyText:
The Isle Royale Light stands on long, rocky Menagerie Island via Isle Royale's south shore at the entry to Siskiwit Bay. Reachable only by private boat, it features a 61-foot double-walled octagonal sandstone tower, with a black lantern and gallery. It was completed and operative in 1875, and automated in 1913. The original Fourth Order Fresnel lens and subsequent light systems have been replaced with a 12-volt solar power 300 mm Tidelands Signal Acrylic Optic, which sends its beam out 10 miles.

Learn about the history of the Isle Royale Lighthouse.

Explore the History & Culture of Isle Royale National Park.
audioDescription: Isle Royale Lighthouse is located on the south shore of Isle Royale National Park near Malone Bay Dock and Campground. The lighthouse is located on Menagerie Island. Reachable only by private boat, it features a 61-foot double-walled octagonal sandstone tower, with a black lantern and gallery.

title: Isle Royale Queen IV
listingDescription: The Isle Royale Queen IV passenger ferry is based out of Copper Harbor, Michigan.

images.altText: Isle Royale Queen IV, a passenger ferry, on Lake Superior.
images.title: Isle Royale Queen IV
images.caption: The QUEEN IV operates between Copper Harbor, Michigan and Rock Harbor on Isle Royale.

bodyText:
About

The Isle Royale Queen IV passenger ferry operates between Copper Harbor, Michigan and Rock Harbor on the northeast end of Isle Royale National Park. There is no car ferry service.

Schedule

Throughout the season the ship's schedule varies; it typically operates from early May through the end of September.

The Isle Royale Queen IV departs Copper Harbor, Michigan at 8:00 am EDT and takes a little over three hours to arrive at Rock Harbor. The ship then departs Rock Harbor at 2:45 pm EDT for Copper Harbor. The Isle Royale Queen IV makes the departure and return trip on the same day, allowing for both overnight and day-trip passengers.

Reservations

For schedules, fare information, or to make reservations, please visit the Isle Royale Queen IV website.

Park Entrance Fees

A per person daily entrance fee is required to enter and remain in the park. Pay fees online prior to your trip.

Park Newspaper

Utilize the park's newspaper, The Greenstone, for all of your transportation and trip planning needs.
audioDescription: The Isle Royale Queen IV is a passenger ferry based in Copper Harbor, Michigan that services Isle Royale National Park.

title: Isle Royale Seaplanes
listingDescription: Gain a bird's perspective and travel to Isle Royale by seaplane with Isle Royale Seaplanes.

images.altText: Seaplane with Isle Royale Seaplanes company sits on the water in a cove at Isle Royale National Park
images.title: Isle Royale Seaplane
images.caption: See the island from a bird's eye view with Isle Royale Seaplanes.

bodyText:
About

Isle Royale Seaplanes is the sole concessionaire offering seaplane transportation to Isle Royale National Park. Their main office and contact center is in Hancock, Michigan along the Keweenaw Waterway. Flights originate from there and from the Cook County Airport in Grand Marais, Minnesota. Both departure bases provide service to Windigo and Rock Harbor. 

Schedule

Throughout the operating season the seaplane's schedule varies; it typically operates from mid-May through mid-September. Overnight and day-trip visits are offered.

Delays
Travel delays can occur due to fog and inclement weather. Usually delays are for a few hours; however delays can stretch over multiple days. Whether arriving or departing the island, be prepared for all travel possibilities.

Reservations

For schedules, fare information, or to make a reservation, please visit the Isle Royale Seaplanes website.

Park Entrance Fees

A per person daily entrance fee is required to enter and remain in the park. Pay fees online prior to your trip.

Permits

After disembarking the seaplane at either Rock Harbor or Windigo, visitors are required to self-check in. 

  • Backpackers and Campers: Use the Self-Permit Station to collect and write a camping permit, following provided instructions. Note method of park entrance fee payment on permit. Each party collects one permit.
  • Daytrippers: Use the same Self-Permit Station to self-certify that park entrance fees have been paid prior to arrival.
  • Groups (Parties of 7 or More People): Do not use Self-Permit Station. Proceed inside the visitor center to retrieve your permit. 

Self-Permit Station Locations:

  • Rock Harbor: Event tent outside of Rock Harbor Visitor Center

  • Windigo: Far side of Windigo Visitor Center deck

Park Newspaper

Utilize the park's newspaper, The Greenstone, for all of your transportation and trip planning needs.
audioDescription: Isle Royale Seaplanes services seaplane trips to and from Isle Royale out of Houghton/Hancock, Michigan and Grand Marais, Minnesota.

title: Lookout Louise
listingDescription: Lookout Louise is a popular scenic overlook at the east end of Isle Royale National Park, capturing a view of Thunder Bay across roughly 15 miles of Lake Superior.

images.altText: a view from the Lookout Louise overlook of Duncan Bay and the distant islands of Ontario
images.title: Lookout Louise
images.caption: View from Lookout Louise on a clear day.

bodyText: Lookout Louise is a popular overlook perched over Duncan Bay and commanding a view of the stretch of Lake Superior between Isle Royale and Thunder Bay, Ontario. On a clear day, Pie Island, the Sibley Peninsula, and Edward Island are visible. Those with binoculars are afforded a view of the buildings dotting Sibley Cove, an old silver mining town developed in the 1870s. Lookout Louise is named after Louise Savage of Saint Paul, Minnesota, a girl whose family owned one of the nearby Tobin Harbor islands before Isle Royale's days as a national park.
audioDescription: Elevated roughly 300 feet above Duncan Bay, this overlook provides an unobstructed view of the rocky north shore of the island, and on a clear day the roughly 15 to 20 miles that separate Isle Royale from the Ontario mainland. It is not uncommon to be visited by eagles on this platform and spy large maritime vessels carrying freight to and from Thunder Bay. Evident is the island's ridge and valley topography from this view, with layers of lakes and trees interwoven in the foreground below. There is almost no evidence of human construction from this view unless binoculars are used to gain a clearer view of the Ontario shoreline.

title: Minong Ridge Overlook
listingDescription: The Minong Ridge Overlook on the west end of Isle Royale National Park is a scenic stop for day hikers and backpackers alike.

images.altText: View from the Minong Ridge Overlook looking northward during the fall.
images.title: Minong Ridge Overlook
images.caption: The Canadian shoreline can be seen from the Minong Ridge Overlook.

bodyText:
The Minong Ridge Overlook sits along the Minong Ridge Trail on the west end of Isle Royale National Park. The overlook is signified by the first rocky ridge when traveling from the west. Hikers can enjoy views of the island’s west end, Lake Superior, and the Canadian shoreline to the north. 

Found Nearby

  • Windigo Area

  • Huginning Cove Campground

  • North Lake Desor Campground
audioDescription: The Minong Ridge Overlook is located along the Minong Ridge Trail on the west end of Isle Royale National Park. The overlook sits upon an exposed rocky ridge. Views of the island’s west end, Minong Ridge, and the Candian shoreline to the north can be enjoyed from the overlook.

title: Minong Ridge Trailhead: McCargoe Cove
listingDescription: Embark on a challenging adventure and backpack the Minong Ridge Trail on Isle Royale starting at McCargoe Cove.

images.altText: Wooden trail marker for the Minong Ride Trail, surrounded by rocks and forest.
images.title: Minong Ridge Trail Marker
images.caption: The Minong Ridge Trail is one of the most rugged trails on Isle Royale.

bodyText:
Thinking about backpacking the Minong Ridge Trail at Isle Royale National Park? This challening trail stretches along the northern portion of the island and offers scenic views of Lake Superior and the Canadian shoreline. This primitive trail is strenuous due to its change in elevation, rocky ridges, and beaver dam crossings. Hikers need to utitlize wayfinding and orienteering skills on this trail. 

Miles: about 28 miles. 

Trailhead Locations

  • Windigo is accessible by ferry, seaplane, or private boat.
  • McCargoe is accessible by trail, Voyageur II passenger ferry, or private boat.


Accessibility: This backcountry trail is about 18 inches wide and includes rocks and roots. Trail includes wooden plank bridges, steep inclines, and trail sections that involve beaver dam crossings. Trekking poles are useful for this hike. No potable water is available along this trail. Bring everything you need to backpack multiple days including enough food, water filter, map, and compass. 

Campgrounds Along Trail
•  McCargoe Cove Campground
•  Todd Harbor Campground
•  Little Todd Campground
•  North Lake Desor Campground
•  Huginnin Cove Campground
•  Washington Creek Campground
audioDescription: The Minong Ridge Trail is the most challenging trail on Isle Royale. The trail is composed of rocky ridges, elevation change, beaver dams, interior lakes, Lake Superior and Canadian shoreline views.

title: Minong Ridge Trailhead: Windigo
listingDescription: Embark on a challenging adventure and backpack the Minong Ridge Trail on Isle Royale starting at Windigo.

images.altText: Wooden trail marker for the Minong Ride Trail, surrounded by rocks and forest.
images.title: Minong Ridge Trail Marker
images.caption: The Minong Ridge Trail is one of the most rugged trails on Isle Royale.

bodyText:
Thinking about backpacking the Minong Ridge Trail at Isle Royale National Park? This challening trail stretches along the northern portion of the island and offers scenic views of Lake Superior and the Canadian shoreline. This primitive trail is strenuous due to its change in elevation, rocky ridges, and beaver dam crossings. Hikers need to utitlize wayfinding and orienteering skills on this trail. 

Miles: about 28 miles. 

Trailhead Locations

  • Windigo is accessible by ferry, seaplane, or private boat.
  • McCargoe is accessible by trail, Voyageur II passenger ferry, or private boat.

Accessibility: This backcountry trail is about 18 inches wide and includes rocks and roots. Trail includes wooden plank bridges, steep inclines, and trail sections that involve beaver dam crossings. Trekking poles are useful for this hike. No potable water is available along this trail. Bring everything you need to backpack multiple days including enough food, water filter, map, and compass. 

Campgrounds Along Trail
•  McCargoe Cove Campground
•  Todd Harbor Campground
•  Little Todd Campground
•  North Lake Desor Campground
•  Huginnin Cove Campground
•  Washington Creek Campground
audioDescription: The Minong Ridge Trail is the most challenging trail on Isle Royale. The trail is composed of rocky ridges, elevation change, beaver dams, interior lakes, Lake Superior and Canadian shoreline views.

title: Mount Franklin
listingDescription: Mount Franklin is a a scenic hike destination for day hikers and backpackers on Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: From the top of Mt. Franklin Lake Superior and the Canadian shoreline can be seen.
images.title: Mount Franklin
images.caption: View from Mt. Franklin looking north to the Canadian shoreline.

bodyText:
Mount Franklin is a scenic overlook along the Greenstone Ridge Trail on the east end of Isle Royale National Park. This rocky viewpoint honors Benjamin Franklin. Mount Franklin is accessible from Rock Harbor via the Rock Harbor or Tobin Harbor Trails. It is a popular and challenging 10 mile round trip day hike from Rock Harbor. Hike to Mount Franklin and view the island’s interior and north shore as well as the distant Canadian mainland. 

Found Nearby

  • Greenstone Ridge Trail
  • Lane Cove & Campground (2.7 miles away)
  • Three Mile Campground (2.3 miles away)
  • Ojibway Tower (2.5 miles away)
  • Rock Harbor Area (4.5 miles away)
audioDescription: Mount Franklin is located along the Greenstone Ridge Trail on the east end of Isle Royale National Park. This scenic hike destination offers views of the Canadian shoreline to the north. Mount Franklin is a popular day hike destination from the Rock Harbor Area.

title: Ojibway Tower
listingDescription: Ojibway Tower is an old fire tower, converted to a telecommunications tower, located on the East End of Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: Ojibway Tower pierces a cloudy sky on a ridgetop.
images.title: Ojibway Tower
images.caption: Ojibway Tower is a scenic stop along the Greenstone Ridge Trail.

bodyText:
Ojibway Tower is located on the Greenstone Ridge on Isle Royale National Park. Ojibway Tower is the highest point on the eastern end of Isle Royale. Formerly a fire watch station, the tower room today holds telecommunication equipment that helps support park operations. The tower room is closed, but visitors may climb partway up the stairs for views of the island’s interior lakes and bays. The tower is a popular scenic viewpoint along the Greenstone Ridge Trail. Hiking access is available from Daisy Farm Campground and the Greenstone Ridge Trail. Boats may dock at the Daisy Farm Dock and hike to the tower. Daily boat rentals are available from the Rock Harbor Marina. 

Found Nearby

  • Daisy Farm Campground (1.7 miles away)

  • Mount Franklin (2.8 miles away)

  • Rock Harbor Lighthouse
audioDescription: Ojibway Tower, located on the east end of Isle Royale National Park, offers a unique Isle Royale 360 degree view. The tower sits on a rocky ridge top. Visitors may climb part way up the tower and enjoy views of the Island’s interior lakes and bays. The tower can be accessed from the Greenstone Ridge Trail and Daisy Farm Campground.

title: Passage Island Lighthouse
listingDescription: On the northeast side of Isle Royale National Park, the Passage Island Light guides ship traffic between the channel of Isle Royale's main island and Passage Island.

images.altText: lighthouse, communication tower, and garage structure on a rocky island
images.title: Passage Island Lighthouse
images.caption: Guarding the primary maritime passage between Thunder Bay and the open lake.

bodyText:
On the northeast side of Isle Royale National Park, the Passage Island Lighthouse guides ship traffic between the channel of Isle Royale's main island and Passage Island. Completed in 1882, the lighthouse originally used a Fourth Order oil-burning wick lamp and appeared as a fixed red light; later, it was modified to a flashing white light. Concession tours travel to the island, giving visitors a glimpse of this now automated and unmanned sentinel of the past that continues to provide safe passage to ships today.

Learn about the history of the Passage Island Lighthouse.

Explore the History & Culture of Isle Royale National Park.
audioDescription: Passage Island Lighthouse is located on Passage Island, northeast of the main island of Isle Royale National Park.

title: Rainbow Cove
listingDescription: A scenic spot located on Isle Royale’s southwestern shore, Rainbow Cove is a rocky beach with excellent opportunities to view sunsets, the historic Rock of Ages Lighthouse, and the Minnesota shoreline

images.altText: Lake Superior shoreline meets a rocky beach with trees in the distance.
images.title: Rainbow Cove
images.caption: Hike 0.8 miles from Feldtmann Lake to Rainbow Cove and catch an island sunset.

bodyText:
Rainbow Cove is located on the west end of Isle Royale National Park. Access is available via the 0.8 of a mile access trail from the Feldtmann Lake Campground, kayak/canoe, or private vessel. The entire cove is covered in rocks. On a clear day, the Rock of Ages Lighthouse and Minnesota shoreline can be viewed from the beach. This remote beach is a picturesque sunset destination. 

Found Nearby

  • Feldtmann Lake Campground (0.8 miles away)
  • Feldtmann Tower (5.6 miles away)
  • Windigo Area (8.5 miles away)
  • Rock of Ages Lighthouse
audioDescription: Rainbow Cove is located on Lake Superior, on the Southwest shore of Isle Royale National Park. The cove includes a rocky beach and scenic views of Lake Superior. The historic Rock of Ages Lighthouse and Minnesota shoreline can be seen in the distance on a clear day. Visitors may catch beautiful sunsets.

title: Ranger III
listingDescription: The Ranger III, the largest vessel operated by the NPS, serves as the logistical backbone of Isle Royale National Park, operating as the main cargo vessel to the island and the flagship passenger transporter. The USNPS Ranger III has been serving Isle Royale since September 8, 1958.

images.altText: large blue and white cargo ship docked, with name 'RANGER III' clearly visible on bow
images.title: RANGER III
images.caption: The USNPS RANGER III docked at Mott Island.

bodyText:
About

The Ranger III is a passenger and freight ferry operated by Isle Royale National Park. The Ranger III makes passenger trips from Houghton, Michigan to Rock Harbor on Isle Royale. The Ranger III takes approximately 6 hours to cross Lake Superior each way. The Ranger III has made over 4,000 Lake Superior crossings throughout its history. Each of these voyages brought supplies and family connections to island rangers, and visitors whose park memories began when they first stepped aboard. Learn more about the largest operating vessel in the National Park Service, The Ranger III. 

Schedule

Passenger service is offered from the end of May through early September annually. See the current Ranger III schedule. 

Reservations

Ranger III reservations can be made online before your trip. 
 

Park Newspaper

Utilize the park's newspaper, The Greenstone, for all of your transportation and trip planning needs.
audioDescription: The Ranger III is a 165 foot long, 34 feet wide, 648 ton vessel that carries 128 passengers.

passportStampImages.altText: image of passport date stamp for USNPS Ranger III
passportStampImages.title: USNPS Ranger III Passport Stamp

title: Rock Harbor Comfort Station
listingDescription: Bathroom services are found at the Rock Harbor Comfort Station on the east end of Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: A paved path leads to a bathroom building surrounded by trees.
images.title: Rock Harbor Comfort Station
images.caption: Bathroom services are offered at the Rock Harbor Comfort Station on the east end of Isle Royale.

bodyText:
The Rock Harbor Comfort Station is found on the east end of Isle Royale National Park. Flush toilets and running water are open to the public seasonally. Shower and laundry services are available for an extra fee. Shower and laundry tokens can be purchased through the Rock Harbor Camp Store. 

Found Nearby

  • Rock Harbor Visitor Center

  • Rock Harbor Camp Store

  • Rock Harbor Campground

  • Rock Harbor Lodge

  • Rock Harbor Marina

  • Rock Harbor Trail

  • Tobin Harbor Trail
audioDescription: A building including bathrooms, showers, and laundry services is located in Rock Harbor on the east end of Isle Royale National Park. It is found directly north of the Rock Harbor Visitor Center and Rock Harbor Camp Store.

title: Rock Harbor Lighthouse
listingDescription: The Rock Harbor Lighthouse at the southwest entrance to Rock Harbor is the most viewed and visited lighthouse at Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: a view of the Rock Harbor Lighthouse from the waters of Middle Islands Passage on a bright blue day
images.title: Rock Harbor Lighthouse
images.caption: Lighthouse standing on the edge of the Saginaw Peninsula, protecting the Middle Islands Passage.

bodyText:
Although no longer illuminated, the Rock Harbor Light at the southwest entrance to Rock Harbor is the most viewed and visited lighthouse. Completed in 1855, it features a 50-foot white round brick tower with a black lantern. The tower is attached to a keep's house that now serves as a museum. A Fourth Order Fresnel Lens once sent out a beacon of light for 15 miles across the lake. In 1859, as copper mining declined, the Rock Harbor Light was shut down, but the light was rekindled in 1874 when copper mining resurged. In 1879, it was permanently closed, but remains a popular tour stop for visitors today.

Learn about the history of the Rock Harbor Lighthouse.

Explore the History & Culture of Isle Royale National Park.
audioDescription: Rock Harbor Lighthouse marks the entrance to Rock Harbor at the Middle Islands Passage. The white brick makes the lighthouse stick out on the shoreline.

title: Rock Harbor Lodge
listingDescription: The shore front Rock Harbor Lodge found on Isle Royale National Park’s east end provides many visitor services.

images.altText: Buildings a part of the Rock Harbor Lodge sit on the shore of Lake Superior with a forest in back.
images.title: Rock Harbor Lodge ISRO
images.caption: Rock Harbor Lodge offers lodging accommodations near Rock Harbor.

bodyText:
The Rock Harbor Lodge complex is the only full-service lodging facility on the island. The Rock Harbor Lodge is located on the northeastern end of Isle Royale National Park in Rock Harbor. Facilities and services are available seasonally (typically June-September). Services include lodge rooms, housekeeping rooms, gift shop and dockside store, dining room and Greenstone Grill, Rock Harbor Marina, water taxi, fishing and sightseeing charters, and motor boat, kayak, and canoe rentals.

Found Nearby

  • Rock Harbor Visitor Center
  • Rock Harbor Store
  • Rock Harbor Campground
  • Rock Harbor Comfort Station
  • Rock Harbor Marina
audioDescription: The Rock Harbor Lodge, on the shores of Lake Superior, is located on Isle Royale’s east end. In the heart of Rock Harbor, the Lodge is accessible via ferry, private boat, or seaplane. The wide and accessible paths near the Lodge connect to the Rock Harbor Visitor Center, Rock Harbor Store, and the Rock Harbor Campground.

title: Rock Harbor Marina
listingDescription: The Rock Harbor Marina on Isle Royale National Park’s northeastern end is a portal to wilderness for private vessels.

images.altText: Two sailboats docked at the Rock Harbor Marina.
images.title: Rock Harbor Marina
images.caption: Sailboats find port at the Rock Harbor Marina.

bodyText:
The Rock Harbor Marina is located in the heart of Rock Harbor, on the northeastern end of Isle Royale National Park. Private vessels may stay overnight for an extra fee. The Rock Harbor Marina has 450’ of dock space and accommodates boats up to 65’. Services available: electrical and fresh water hook-ups, sewage pump-out service, gasoline, and diesel fuel. Canoe, kayak, and motorboat half-day or full day rentals are also available at the marina. Private boats in park waters need to pay daily fees and acquire a boating permit from any Visitor Center or online. 

Found Nearby

  • Rock Harbor Visitor Center

  • Rock Harbor Store

  • Rock Harbor Lodge

  • Rock Harbor Trail

  • Tobin Harbor Trail
audioDescription: The Rock Harbor Marina is located on the northeastern end of Isle Royale National Park. It is located near downtown Rock Harbor. Overnight stays by private vessels are permitted for an extra fee. This portal to wilderness offers access to a variety of visitor services.

title: Rock Harbor Store
listingDescription: The Rock Harbor Store offers a standard selection of groceries and more on the east end of Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: Rock Harbor Store structure located next to Rock Harbor Dock.
images.title: Rock Harbor Store
images.caption: Forget something? The Rock Harbor Store offers a standard selection of groceries.

bodyText:
The Rock Harbor Store is located on the main dock in Rock Harbor, on the east end of Isle Royale National Park. Store offers camping, hiking, and boating supplies, groceries, freeze-dried foods, fishing tackle, stove fuel, showers, and laundry. Dockside store open seasonally from 5/22 through 9/11. 

Found Nearby

  • Rock Harbor Visitor Center

  • Rock Harbor Marina

  • Rock Harbor Campground

  • Rock Harbor Lodge
audioDescription: The Rock Harbor Store is located in Rock Harbor on Isle Royale’s east end. Found right in downtown Rock Harbor across from the Rock Harbor Visitor Center. The Rock Harbor Dock and Marina are just a few steps from the store. Rock Harbor is a developed area that acts as a portal to the vast wilderness of Isle Royale National Park.

title: Rock of Ages Lighthouse
listingDescription: Just outside Washington Harbor stands the Rock of Ages Light, which began operation in 1908. The 117-foot white cylinder-shaped lighthouse is composed of steel, concrete, and brick, with a black base and lantern.

images.altText: image of a lighthouse jutting up from a desolate, tiny rocky reef
images.title: Rock of Ages Lighthouse
images.caption: Rock of Ages guards the formidable reef that it sits on.

bodyText:
Just outside Washington Harbor stands the Rock of Ages Light, which began operation in 1908. The 117-foot white cylinder-shaped lighthouse is composed of steel, concrete, and brick, with a black base and lantern. To build this lighthouse on a 50-foot by 200-foot rocky outcrop was a tribute to the engineering of the time. In 1909, a Second Order Fresnel lens replaced the first, temporary Third Order fixed red light. Today, the unmanned lighthouse features a 300 mm Tideland Signal Acrylic Optic lens that runs on solar power. You can view the stunning old Second Order Fresnel lens at the Windigo Visitor Center.

Learn about the history of the Rock of Ages Lighthouse.

Explore the History & Culture of Isle Royale National Park.
audioDescription: The Rock of Ages Lighthouse is located 8 miles from Windigo and 4 miles from the mouth of Washington Harbor, on the western end of Isle Royale National Park. The lighthouse sits on a rock surrounded by Lake Superior.

title: Sea Hunter III
listingDescription: SEA HUNTER III passenger ferry services makes day trips to Isle Royale.

images.altText: The Sea Hunter III, a white ferry, docked along a large wooden dock. Lightly clouded sky above.
images.title: SEA HUNTER III
images.caption: The SEA HUNTER III makes day trips to Windigo.

bodyText:
About

The Sea Hunter III is a 65' foot twin diesel vessel that provides passenger service to Isle Royale National Park. It operates between Grand Portage, MN and Windigo, MI on the southwest end of the island. There is no car ferry service. Day-trip and overnight visits are offered. Grand Portage, MN is in the central time zone, and the Sea Hunter III schedule operates on central time. Isle Royale National Park is in the eastern time zone, and operates on eastern time. It is recommended to stay on central time during your trip.
 

Throughout the operating season the Sea Hunter III's schedule varies; it typically operates from mid-June through Labor Day.

  • The Sea Hunter III departs Grand Portage, MN at 8:30 am CDT / 9:30 am EDT and arrives at Windigo at 10:00 am CDT / 11:00 am EDT.
  • Visitors on the day-trip have four hours to explore the west end of the park.
  • The Sea Hunter III departs Windigo at 2:00 pm CDT / 3:00 pm EDT and arrives at Grand Portage, MN at 3:30 pm CDT / 4:30 pm EDT.

Reservations

For additional schedule, fare information, or to make a reservation, please visit the Sea Hunter III website.

Park Entrance Fees

A per person daily entrance fee is required to enter and remain in the park. Pay fees online prior to your trip.

Park Newspaper

Utilize the park's newspaper, The Greenstone, for all of your transportation and trip planning needs.
audioDescription: The Sea Hunter III is a passenger ferry that services Isle Royale from Grand Portage, Minnesota.
managedByOrg: Grand Portage Isle Royale Transportation Lines

title: Suzy's Cave
listingDescription: Observe the lasting impact of wave action at Suzy’s Cave- an inland sea arch on Isle Royale National Park, formed over 4,000 years ago.

images.altText: View of rocky outcropping with a dark cave.
images.title: Suzy's Cave
images.caption: Discover Suzy's Cave, an inland sea arch.

bodyText:
Suzy's Cave is located on the east end of Isle Royale National Park. It is a popular short hike from the Rock Harbor area. Suzy’s Cave includes an inland sea arch formed by wave action some 4000 years ago when water levels were higher. The cave is located between Three Mile Campground and Rock Harbor. Rock Harbor can be accessed via the Tobin Harbor Trail or the Rock Harbor Trail. The 1.8 mile Rock Harbor Trail is difficult and includes rocks and roots, tread carefully. The 1.8 mile Tobin Harbor Trail is significantly smoother. There is a .2 mile spur trail that connects the two trails to Suzy’s Cave.

Found Nearby

  • Three Mile Campground (1.8 miles away)

  • Rock Harbor Area (1.8 miles away)
audioDescription: Suzy’s Cave includes a wave-washed cliff and an inland sea arch, both were formed by wave action about 4000 years ago when water levels were higher. The cave is located on the southeast end of Isle Royale between Three Mile Campground and Rock Harbor. The Tobin Harbor and Rock Harbor Trails lead to Rock Harbor. Both trails are 1.8 miles, but the Tobin Harbor Trail is significantly smoother. A .2 mile spur trail connects the two trails to Suzy’s Cave. Listen carefully for wildlife through a thick canopy of spruce, fir, and birch.

title: Voyageur II
listingDescription: The Voyageur II is a passenger ferry based in Minnesota that services Isle Royale.

images.altText: The VOYAGEUR II arrives at the Windigo dock at Isle Royale.
images.title: VOYAGEUR II
images.caption: The VOYAGEUR II connects the island to Minnesota.

bodyText:
About

The Voyageur II is a 65' twin engine diesel vessel that provides mail and passenger service to Isle Royale National Park. It operates between Grand Portage, Minnesota and numerous drop-off and pick-up locations along the north and south shores of the island. Overnight visits are offered. There is no car ferry service. The Voyageur II runs on central time, whereas Isle Royale National Park is on eastern time; it is recommended to stay on central time during your trip.

Schedule

Throughout the season the vessel's schedule varies; it typically operates from early May through early October. The Voyageur II typically provides service around Isle Royale every two days, staying overnight in Rock Harbor. It does not operate on Fridays.

Outbound Schedule

  • Depart: Grand Portage, MN: 7:30 am CDT / 8:30 am EDT
  • Arrive: Windigo, Isle Royale : 9:30 am CDT / 10:30 am EDT
  • Depart: Windigo, Isle Royale: 10:00 am CDT / 11:00 am EDT
  • Arrive and Depart: McCargoe Cove, Isle Royale: 1:00 pm CDT / 2:00 p.m. EDT
  • Arrive and Depart: Belle Isle, Isle Royale: 1:30 pm CDT / 2:30 pm EDT
  • Arrive: Rock Harbor, Isle Royale: 3:00 pm CDT / 4:00 pm EDT

Inbound Schedule

  • Depart: Rock Harbor, Isle Royale: 8:00 am CDT / 9:00 am EDT

  • Depart and Arrive: Daisy Farm, Isle Royale: 8:30 am CDT / 9:30 am EDT
  • Depart and Arrive: Chippewa Harbor, Isle Royale: 9:00 am CDT / 10:00 am EDT
  • Depart and Arrive: Malone Bay, Isle Royale: 10:00 am CDT / 11:00 am EDT
  • Arrive: Windigo, Isle Royale: 12:30 pm CDT / 1:30 pm EDT
  • Depart: Windigo, Isle Royale: 1:00 pm CDT / 2:00 pm EDT
  • Arrive: Grand Portage, MN: 3:00 pm CDT / 4:00 pm EDT

Stops at McCargoe Cove, Daisy Farm, Chippewa Harbor, and Malone Bay only occur when pick-ups and drop-offs are arranged ahead of time.

Reservations

For additional schedule, fare information, or to make reservations, please visit the Voyageur II website.

Park Entrance Fees

A per person daily entrance fee is required to enter and remain in the park. Pay fees online prior to your trip.

Park Newspaper

Utilize the park's newspaper, The Greenstone, for all of your transportation and trip planning needs.
audioDescription: The Voyageur II is a passenger ferry based out of Grand Portage, Minnesota that services Isle Royale National Park.

title: Windigo Camper Cabins
listingDescription: Stay at the rustic Windigo Camper Cabins on the west end of Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: A rustic cabin sits on top of a forested hill in Windigo on the west end of Isle Royale.
images.title: Windigo Camper Cabins
images.caption: Stay at the Windigo Camper Cabins and enjoy a rustic lodging experience on the island.

bodyText:
The Windigo Camper Cabins are found on the west end of Isle Royale National Park in Windigo. Two cabins ran by Isle Royale Resorts are available for reservation. Each cabin accommodates up to six people. Cabins are furnished with table, chairs, full size futon, bunk beds with mattresses, electrical outlets and lighting. Each cabin has a picnic table and propane grill. Water spigot and privy are nearby. 

Found Nearby

  • Windigo Visitor Center
  • Windigo Camp Store
  • Windigo Marina
audioDescription: The Windigo Camper Cabins are located in Windigo on the west end of Isle Royale National Park. Two rustic cabins and a privy are found on the hill behind the Windigo Visitor Center. A gravel trail passes by the cabins and gives access to the Windigo area and nearby trailheads. Reservations for the cabins need to be made in advance through Isle Royale Resorts.

title: Windigo Comfort Station
listingDescription: Bathrooms, showers, and laundry services can be found at the Windigo Comfort Station at Isle Royale National Park.

images.altText: A building with four doors, two benches, and two pillars.
images.title: Windigo Comfort Station
images.caption: The Windigo Comfort Station offers bathrooms, showers, and laundry services.

bodyText:
The Windigo Comfort Station offers bathroom services in Windigo on the west end of Isle Royale National Park. Flush toilets and running water are open to the public seasonally. Showers and laundry services are offered for an extra fee. Shower and laundry tokens can be purchased through the Windigo Camp Store. 

Found Nearby

  • Windigo Visitor Center
  • Windigo Camp Store
  • Windigo Marina
  • Washington Creek Campground
  • Washington Harbor
  • Feldtmann Lake Trail
  • Greenstone Ridge Trail
  • Minong Ridge Trail
audioDescription: The Windigo Camp Store is located in Windigo on the west end of Isle Royale National Park. It is found along Washington Harbor near the Windigo Marina, Windigo Camp Store, and the Windigo Visitor Center. Restrooms are open to the public seasonally. Showers and laundry services are offered seasonally for an extra fee paid through the Windigo Camp Store.

title: Windigo Marina
listingDescription: A portal to wilderness, the Windigo Marina is located on Isle Royale National Park’s southwest end and is easily accessible by private boat, ferry, or seaplane.

images.altText: The sun sets over Washington Harbor and the Windigo Dock.
images.title: Windigo Marina
images.caption: Catch a glimpse of a Washington Harbor sunset at the Windigo Marina.

bodyText:
The Windigo Marina is located on the southwestern end of Isle Royale within Washington Harbor, 22 miles from the Minnesota shoreline. This dock is accessible from Grand Portage Marina via the Sea Hunter, Voyager II, or private boat. The consecutive night stay limit is five nights effective from June 1st - Labor Day annually. Wildlife sightings are common here. Enjoy the magic of the west end with Washington Harbor sunsets. Private boats in park waters need to pay daily fees and acquire a boating permit from any Visitor Center or online. Services available: gasoline and diesel fuel, sewage pump-out, and motorboat, canoe, and kayak rentals. 

Found Nearby

  • Windigo Visitor Center
  • Windigo Comfort Station
  • Windigo Camp Store
  • Washington Creek Campground
  • Windigo Moose Exclosure
audioDescription: The Windigo Marina located in Washington Harbor, which opens to Lake Superior, the largest amongst the Great Lakes. Historic fisheries and resorts are a welcoming site along the outer islands of Washington Harbor. The Windigo Marina welcomes visitors as they round Beaver Island. Find port on the large wooden dock located between the Windigo Comfort Station and the Pavilion. Wildlife sightings are common here possibly including moose, fox, loons, osprey, grebes, mergansers, and more.
